_common.shortDescription: Learn how to build and execute IBM App Connect Enterprise unit tests outside the Toolkit development environment.

outcomeList.title: As part of an automated process, use IBM App Connect Enterprise to record message assembly files which represent the in-memory logical tree used as messages travel through a deployed message flow.
Execute the ibmint generate tests command to use the recorded messages for the automated construction of Java unit tests.

summary._overviewComment: A short description of what happens in this tutorial, and an optional short explanation of the ACE concepts used in this tutorial if necessary for context. What background knowledge must the user have for this to make sense?

sections.section: This tutorial assumes you have already written a message flow and have some unit tests which you would like to run. Other tutorials in the gallery provide details for how to create unit tests manually or automatically generate them for existing message flows, so if you don't already know how to do this it is recommended to complete one of those tutorials first and then return to this scenario. This tutorial provides a simple message flow in an application, and a corresponding set of tests. In this example, the tests were generated using the ibmint generate tests command, but the method dscribed in this tutorial could also be applied to tests that you have authored using the Toolkit's features.

The tutorial provides the message flow already constructed, recorded message assembly files and some associated unit tests in a Test Project.  We will import these projects into the Toolkit, but then switch to a command console session to demonstrate how to build and execute the tests outside the Toolkit.

sections.section: Click Import and the application named MyApplicationToBeTested, and the test project named GeneratedTestProject will be added to your workspace.

MyApplicationToBeTested provides a single message flow named MyMessageFlowToBeTested which receives data over HTTP. The project also provides 10 sample input messages. These inputs have also been used to generate a set of unit tests which reside in the Test project named GeneratedTestProject.

The HTTPInput node is configured to expect a JSON message which carries a single field containing a number. There follows a series of Filter nodes and graphical mapping nodes in the flow which test the input to see whether it is exactly divisible by 3 and exactly divisible by 2. The results drive the message down alternate branches of the flow all of which ultimately pass in to an HTTPReply node at the end of the flow which responds back to the requestor.
Now move to the Prepare section where we will leave the Toolkit and use a command console session to build the tests, which will then be executed in the Run section of the tutorial.

sections.section: Build the provided unit tests into a jar file from a command line

details.details:
Launch a command console session, and change directory to the location of the Test project named GeneratedTestProject in your Toolkit workspace (in the example below this is C:\MyToolkitWorkspace\GeneratedTestProject). This Test project, which was imported in the Create stage of the tutorial, contains a file build.gradle and a file settings.gradle which can be used by the Gradle build tool in order to build a jar file containing the JUnit tests. This tutorial assumes you already have gradle installed (if not, you can do this very easily, starting from https://gradle.org/install/). Next, build the tests using the gradle command. The code shown below demonstrates these steps:

The tests are now ready to be executed. Now move to the Run section of the tutorial, where we will use an integration server to execute the built tests.
